These societies were also characterized by the emergence of social hierarchies, with ruling elites and subservient populations. Prehistory refers to the time period before written records existed. It spans from the emergence of the first humans, around 6 million years ago, to the development of writing, which occurred independently in various civilizations around 5,000-6,000 years ago. During this period, humans lived in small groups, hunting and gathering food, and eventually developed more complex societies. Prehistory is often divided into several periods, including the Paleolithic, Mesolithic, and Neolithic eras, which are characterized by the development of tools, language, and agriculture. The study of prehistory is based on archaeological evidence, including artifacts, fossils, and rock art, which provide clues about the lives and cultures of early humans. Understanding prehistory helps us appreciate the evolution of human societies and the development of modern cultures. It also provides a unique perspective on the human experience and our place in the world.
